oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Silver Cord
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Flyer of Sidney Howard's dramatic play called "The Silver Cord." The three act play is about a selfish mother who attempts to keep her children dependent on her. Performance is by Laura Hope Crews and presented by John Cromwell.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Bronx Opera House
oai_dc:dc.dc:coverage: 149th Street, east of Third Avenue, New York, N.Y.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A musical farce comedy called "Oh Johnny!" presented in three acts by Louis Isquith and Joseph S. Klein with Helen Shipman and Lorin Raker performing. Additional actors were Marga Waldron, Joseph McCallion, Frances Halliday, James Marshall, John H. Dunn, Jack Bedord, Robert Webb Lawrence, Helen Mitchell, Harold Ames and Alfred Part. Colorful drawing on program cover of a women holding a black mask drawn by F. Earl Christy. Adaptation rights secured through Mr. Jack Barnes of Freeport, New York.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Adam and Eva
oai_dc:dc.dc:coverage: 48th Street west of Broadway, New York, N.Y.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Postcard advertising the comedic play "Adam and Eva" by Guy Bolton and George Middleton and staged by Robert Milton. The play was presented by F. oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Freeport Amateur Dramatic Association presented T. S. Arthur’s drama “Ten nights in a bar room”. The cast included: Mr. N. B. Mulliner, Mr. J. M. Vincent, Mr. Thomas A. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Freeport Theatre Vaudeville at every performance
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Cover of playbill in color with a picture of Clara Bow promoting the current film “The Plastic Age”. A second film shown was “The Fighting Marine” with Gene Tunney. Upcoming films were “The Speed Limit” with Raymond McKee and “The Shadow on the Wall” with Eileen Percy and Creighton Hale. Additional promotion for a special vaudeville attraction with Julia Rooney, Walter Clinton and orchestra were included.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Hennepin Junior Orpheum Circuit
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Hennepin billed as the northwest’s largest and finest place of amusement. Program for the week of May 21, 1922 showcased Gladys Buckridge, Billy Casey and the Trado Twins in “Ornamental Song Bits”. Additional acts included Shriner & Fitzsimmons, Bill Robinson, The Browne Sisters, The Florinies, Harry Kahne and Conway Tearle. The program highlighted the 125-ton ice plant and 800-ft. artesian well which cooled and ventilated the theater.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Orpheum Circuit News and Program
oai_dc:dc.dc:coverage: O' Farrell between Stockton & Powell, San Francisco, Ca.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Theater program listed Vaudeville acts for the Orpheum Theatre. Acts included: the Orpheum Orchestra that performed music of John Philip Sousa who was a member of the LIGHTS club, a spectacular novelty in two acts with Princess Kalama in “Echoes of Kilauea”, an Italian accordionist Countess Nardini, "Motor Boating" with Tom McRae; the clown act of Bert Melrose, Harry B. Watson and Jere Delaney in "Rubeville", George White and dance partner Emma Haig, Nick Hufford & Dell Chain; the European Equilibrists ‘the Three Jahns’, and Hearst-Pathe News showing notable events. The program included advertisements for the upcoming shows which included Helene Hamilton and Jack Barnes, George White, Emma Haig and Henry B. Toomer & Co. Helene Hamilton and Jack Barnes lived in Freeport at 5 Elm Place.
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: National Program, Co.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Palace Music Hall
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Program for the Winter Garden Company that presented a musical revue in two acts and eleven scenes called “Maid in America.” The revue was staged by J. C. Huffman with music by Sigmund Romberg and Harry Carroll. The cast included Katheryn Andrews, Eddie Cox, Florence Moore, John Sparks, Yvette, Sam Adams, Thomas McGuire, William Gibson, Louise Mink, Hazel Linden, Will Stanton, Jack Coogan, Minerva Coverdale, Bert Clark, Bly Brown, Harold Robe, Rita Gould, Mlle. Dazie, and Swor & Mack. In the chorus were two Freeport residents Roselle Meyers and Florence Ware. The front cover of the program is in color with a women in a pink dress holding a Kabuki style mask.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Princess Theatre
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Theater program for a musical farce comedy in two acts called "Oh Johnny." The book and music were by James Stanley Royce and lyrics by J. Keirn Brennan. The play is from the story "Johnny Walker" and the adaptation rights were secured by Freeport resident, Mr. Jack Barnes. Performances were provided by Shirley Lyons, Marga Waldron, Joe McCallion, Frances Halliday, James Marshall, Lorin Raker, Sir John Dunn, Jack Bedford, Robert Webb Lawrence, Lida Kane, Harold Ames and Alfred Parot. The front cover of the program included a colorful sketch of a woman depicted as a native-American in braided pig-tails.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Robert Hyman
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Bulletin No. 2, Vol. IV for the Princess Stock Company performing a play in four acts by Frances Hodgson Burnett called “The Dawn of a Tomorrow” produced by Elbert & Getchell. Cast in order of appearance: Mr. Hamlin, Mr. Donlan, Mr. Hayden, Mr. Sylvester, Mr. Mitchell, Mr. Noa, Mr. Hyman, Mr. Barnes, Mr. Barbier, Miss Andrews, Miss Hall, Miss Mueller, Miss Fowler, Miss Allen, Mr. Woods and Miss Horne. Mr. Jack Barnes played two characters in the show 'Dr. Satterlee' and 'Lord Tommy'. Mr. Barnes was a Freeport resident and a member of the LIGHTS Club. Review of the prior week’s play “The Girl With the Green Eyes” and the promotion for the following weeks play called “’Bobby’ Brunit” was included.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Sheet music for a waltz ballad entitled "For the sake of Auld Lang Syne" is composed by Ernest R. Ball with lyrics by George Graff and Annelu Burns. Ernest Ball was a member of the LIGHTS club and a resident of Freeport. A picture of Shirley Mason and a gentleman are standing in flowering trees is on the front cover. Shirley Mason who appears in 'Lights of the desert' is wearing a black and white checkered dress. An advertisement for additional sheet music published by M. Witmark & Sons is printed on the back cover.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Original orchestrations for several compositions of music for a Vaudeville performance from the Jack Barnes collection. Titles include: I'm Still Caring, Five Years In One Sentence, Invitation Waltz, Jeannine, I Dream Of Lilac Time, You Better Sing, Where Is The Song Of Songs For Me, Blowing Bubbles, Neapolitan Nights, I'll Get By, Marie, and That's How I Feel About You. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Love Is Like A Blushing Rose
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Von Tilzer, Albert
Fleeson, Neville
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Sheet music for piano and voice entitled "Love is like a Blushing Rose" is composed by Albert Von Tilzer with lyrics by Neville Fleeson. Song is part of the L. Lawrence Weber musical comedy from the book entitled "Bye Bye Bonnie" by Louis Simon and Bide Dudley. Choreography for the show is by Earl Lindsay with staging by Louis Simon. Albert Von Tilzer was a resident of Freeport and lived on Southside Avenue. Advertisements for additional sheet music published by Harms, Inc. is published on the back cover.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Good-Bye Boys
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Von Tilzer, Harry, 1872-1946
Sterling, Andrew B., 1874 - ; Jerome, William, 1865-1932
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Sheet music for piano entitled "Good-Bye Boys" is composed by Harry Von Tilzer with lyrics by Andrew B. Sterling and William Jerome. The song was introduced by Al Jolson in the production of 'The Honeymoon Express' at the Winter Garden Theatre in New York. On the front cover is a photograph of Al Jolson in black face and a portrait of Harry Von Tilzer. An advertisement for sheet music by Harry Von Tilzer is printed on the back cover.
